In light of a certain sequel, I've realized that I never reviewed the original game. So I figured it's time to give this thing the love it deserves.

Hyper Light Drifter is one of the best Zelda-likes I've ever played. We're talking gorgeous pixel-art aesthetics, snappy controls, punishing combat, rewarding exploration, incredible soundtrack, and a shockingly emotional story told entirely through visuals. Seriously, this takes the Ueda/Playdead style of silent narrative and flies with it, telling a deeply personal story with room for interpretation, all in the backdrop of Nausicaa's ecological apocalypse.

The only complaint I've got is that there isn't enough of it. With secrets abound and a tightly crafted world to explore, you're getting your money's worth. But you'll walk away wanting more, only to realize this is wholly unique in its approach. There's nothing else quite like it. 

And I love it for that.

Highly, HIGHLY recommended. One of my favorite games.

185551440.review:
Oh man, I had put off playing this game for years despite it being part of my Steam library for a long time.  I expected to like the opening act and get frustrated by difficulty or strange choices by the designers.  I was ready for disappointment, but it never came.  Instead, I think Hyper Light Drifter may be the best recent game, that is meant to resemble a classic game, that I have ever played.  Of course there's the art-style, but this game is drawing from so many classics with its almost complete absence of dialog and subtle story telling as well as that feeling of almost being completely unsure of where it is you are supposed to go and do.  Then there's the difficulty and the very Zelda-like system of upgrades and power-ups.  It attempts what so many other games have but really gets it right.

Most of the gameplay is top down (ish) with the player hacking, slashing, shooting, and dashing their way across various well-worn video game settings - ice, dessert, swamp, and mountain.  Of course, you collect the equivalent of gems that unlock your path toward a final confrontation, and there are many non-essential secrets and hidden collectibles to find for the eager explorer.  Some light Metroidvania elements also come into play as you'll backtrack a bit once you collect enough doodahs to open those previously inaccessible areas.

Simply put - I loved it.  I wanted my sessions to last longer, and I couldn't wait to jump back in.  It is one of those that I (already) wish I could play again for the first time without knowing anything.  Exceptional experience and an easy 5 out of 5.

[b][h2][u][i]Español[/i][/u][/h2][/b]
Explora, pelea y sobrevive a una aventura que puede tocarte el corazón sin ningún tipo de palabra.

Hyper light Drifter es el primero de Heart Machine. Un proyecto fundado principalmente por artistas y con una carga emocional muy impresa en su desarrollo e historia.

Es un juego de acción y aventura de cámara cenital que puede plantear algunos desafíos.

Su movilidad, aunque no la mas fluida, se integra bien en las circunstancias de la historia y a la vez le da un aspecto único. Tendremos un arsenal de armas distintas, mejoras, habilidades y un movimiento dinámico a base de dashes.

El juego se divide por zonas y su historia esta mas mostrada que contada. No hay escritos, no hay palabras, aunque hay unos objetivos opcionales en idioma propio del juego que nos ayudaran a entender que ocurrió en los lugares que visitamos.

Hablando de los lugares. La ambientación es fantástica, colores vivos, zonas totalmente reconocibles y separadas, pero a la vez que se integran entre ellas. La música también acompaña y aunque no sea una música que nos lleve a un subidón de adrenalina, si que es una banda sonora que nos permite integrarnos mas en el ritmo del juego. 

No hay narrativa, pero el mundo nos contara todo lo que queremos mientras lo exploremos. Es un juego que nos invita a la exploración y es por eso que, si sois más de cosas lineales o mas narrativas, no os lo recomendaría.

En cambio, si quieres un juego con muchos secretos, una jugabilidad a tu ritmo, un pequeño desafío, una historia envuelta en misterio y un mundo que explorar y donde sumergirte. Este es tu juego.

[hr][/hr]
[b][h2][u][i]English[/i][/u][/h2][/b]
Explore, fight, and survive in an adventure that can touch your heart without a single word.

Hyper Light Drifter is Heart Machine's debut game—a project primarily driven by artists and imbued with a deep emotional resonance in its development and story.

It’s an isometric action-adventure game that can present some challenges.

Its movement, while not the most fluid, fits well with the story's circumstances and gives the game a unique feel. You'll have an arsenal of different weapons, upgrades, abilities, and dynamic movement based on dashes.

The game is divided into zones, and its story is more shown than told. There are no written texts or words, although there are optional objectives in the game’s own language that help us understand what happened in the places we visit.

Speaking of the locations: the atmosphere is fantastic. Vibrant colors, entirely distinct and recognizable zones that are seamlessly integrated with one another. The music also complements the experience. While it may not pump you full of adrenaline, the soundtrack does allow you to immerse yourself more deeply in the game's rhythm.

There’s no traditional narrative, but the world will tell you everything you want to know as you explore. It’s a game that invites exploration, so if you prefer linear or heavily narrative-driven games, this might not be for you.

However, if you want a game filled with secrets, gameplay at your own pace, a modest challenge, a story shrouded in mystery, and a world to explore and dive into—this is the game for you.

A pretty good game and would recommend to anybody who hasn't played it and thinks might be their kind of thing. It's good enough that I can't imagine many people disliking it unless it's really not in their preferred genre's at all. Not perfect, in my opinion, but the very few things that niggled at me were far outweighed by the things that I really liked. 

Stand out elements for me were the graphic design and atmosphere. I won't pretend I fully understand what was going on in the story, which is entirely told through visual elements, but I really felt "in" this alien, oppressive and seemingly quite broken and sad world. Sound design was also really nice, further drawing me in. It is worth noting the one time I played with headphones on it felt like it was blowing my ear drums out as soon as there was a cut scene (there aren't many but I happened to hit one in that session) as the volume sliders seem to not apply to them. But all in all this is a captivating experience.

Gameplay was mostly good, occasional frustrations and there were a couple of elements I never really mastered like the dash attacks, but for the most part it feels responsive enough and also open enough to approach in different ways that I found it quite satisfying. Boss fights were good, I only beat one on my first try and most took me a dozen or so attempts to get through, with a couple being roughly double that. Outside of bosses, enemies all demand slightly different approaches, which is cool. They aren't hard individually once you learn what they do, but when mixed and matched it created some challenging scenarios. It's worth noting this game employs check points which can feel quite harsh at times, although in the end I enjoyed it because it forced me to "get good"... or at least less bad, to get through a few of the more tricky sections.

The exploration and secret elements were cool, and players who relish really digging into a game and trying to unlock and see everything may well find this game really scratches that hard to 100% itch. Felt a lot like a metroidvania in that respect. For me I enjoyed trying to find hidden paths and areas as I was going through each level (the game is essentially split into four big levels, with a hub world in between) but found it hard to remember where I had been and hadn't been fairly quickly with-in each of those four sections. I also didn't find the map fairly intuitive to use, and after a couple of hours of backtracking areas trying to find... well... everything, I started to find that quite frustrating and gave up on it, just progressing to the end of the game instead.

Maybe I went into an area that was too advanced for me, but I have no clue how I would know that. There's being mysterious and trusting your players, and then there's just being esoteric. Animal Wells is thirty times better at this than this game.

I saw something about "if you're unfamiliar with Contra or other old school games". Old school games still did their job. They communicated to you what you could do. This game doesn't compare to any of these classics. It makes bad game design decisions just to be harder than the classics. Well of course it's harder, you don't communicate to the player. Contra had power ups in stage one, you didn't have to go digging to find them. There's no comparison here whatsoever, it's just "urgh hard games make me hard" bs. 

I was looking forward to Hyper Light Breaker but if they don't balance out your first time experience, I'm not going to invest in it. Read the book on Blizzard and pay attention to a lesson they learned in an arcade game they developed forever ago where a kid died once and walked away. That was a lesson from thirty years ago.

Fun for some, but not for me.
The colorful pixel art and environmental storytelling caught my interest, but the gameplay takes too many elements from souls-likes with its wild difficulty spikes and heavy feeling combat. Searching for items to progress became so tedious I had no interest in going for 100%.

I can see people enjoying digging into the story with how mysterious it keeps everything, but I got so fed up with how repetitive my issues were with the gameplay that the obscurity the story and direction used for its said mysterious felt more frustrating than anything.

If you like Souls-like combat and vague storytelling, this game does have some merit. I'm just not a fan of it.

184030280.review:
[b]A straightforward combat/exploration game, slightly challenging and clunky.[/b]

Positives:
- It's obvious what to do. There are 4 areas with collectibles and a boss. They are laid out like big Zelda dungeons with a main path, side objectives and lots of challenges.
- Instead of stat upgrades, you can use your collectibles to buy new abilities which drastically enhance the combat. This feels way more rewarding than damage numbers going up.
- No annoying companion or dialog, but there is still some mysterious story.

Neutral:
- There are lots of secrets but for almost all of them it's just a matter of finding a hidden path.
- There are barely any i-frames so tanking damage is not an option. Fighting groups of enemies is challenging and requires use of all combat tools.

Negatives:
- Just focusing on the gameplay and combat mechanics, the game is incredibly clunky and frustrating for no reason. There are absurd challenges like doing 800 dashes in a row. You can get stun-locked easily and there are other problems with collision and platforming.

184029946.review:
Can’t skip cutscenes; that’s always a fun one arrogant developers do. Again, devs if I don’t want to watch your cutscene, you forcing me to watch it isn’t gonna make me appreciate it -if anything-, it’ll make me dislike your game, story, and dev team more.

Presentation is beautiful though, that’s one of the first consolations the game offers for its stupid unskippable cutscenes; it’s not that the pixel art is that detailed or anything like that… it’s more like the developers understood how to use colours and music in conjunction in order to create something beautiful. These are environments that you want to stop and look at, places that you’ll simply enjoy being in, and there’s a sense of aestheticism and preciousness to everything; even when I was fighting, the blood and the enemies seemed to attack and gush from them rhythmically, and in a way that kept the feel of the game intact.

But Christ, the navigation sucks balls, there’s hardly any reasoning behind the map you obtain and unless you’re willing to backtrack or slam yourself against many of the walls scattered throughout the environment, you’ll probably miss some key items required for you to progress… it’s a shame too, because that’s a very crucial aspect of the design of the game that just gets thrown out the window; whilst stuff that seems more inconsequential to the actual design of the game: such as the narrative, or the combat, seems to have been made with a lot more care.

I ended up quitting the game after I couldn’t even get past the first open area the game threw at me, couldn’t even figure out how to get to the first objective because of how obscure (obtuse?) a lot of the level design is like… guess other people might call it “daring” or like a game that “respects players intelligence”… but I don’t think a game that makes me want to waste my time respects me in any way; and that’s kinda like the whole idea behind backtracking, right? To waste my fucking time?

With how janky the combat feels I'm surprised the rating is as high as it is.

[b]I enjoyed[/b] Art, Story and design that is intuitive desipte not having a single English word.

[b]I'm mixed on[/b] exploration, because the world is relatively fun to explore, but exploration follows a pattern to hint where to look, rather than having a cohesive world design. There are lots of invisible walls in places you'd never think to look if they weren't marked.

[b]I'm not a fan of[/b] janky combat. It features a few fun concepts for a classical themed action game, but they implemented the souls-like commitment to attack/dodge (inability to spam) except unlike in souls-likes visuals/animations don't reflect your readyness to followup, which gives it unresponsive feel. Fights against multiple basic enemies (very common) feel bad to me.
